I thought it was a lovely film that probably only Christians will enjoy.  From what I see from the professional critics the ideas of forgiveness, kindness, patience, and love is ludicrous.  It’s a reminder not to give up on people even when they’re difficult to love.

I’m a big fan of Jason Biggs because of the "American Pie" movies, but not even he could save "Best Christmas Ever". The plot is so generic and predictable, and I barely laughed, maybe chuckled a couple of times. There are so many cringe moments, and the child actors are really bad. I didn’t care about any of the characters at all. The story felt like it was written by AI, and some of the emotional stuff, like the death of a kid, made me laugh because it was so unbelievably written.  

Heather Graham was the highlight, though, and probably the only good thing about the movie. Mary Lambert once again proves that she is incapable of directing a film. It also doesn’t know what kind of movie it wants to be; comedy, drama, or something else. Overall, it’s just really badly written and a total waste of time.

Unfortunately this movie was not worth the 81 minutes spent watching it. While the initial premise was lightly based in reality, what ensued was absurdity after absurdity. The characters had absolutely no depth, and we experienced no background to understand their shallowness. Take a hard pass on this and rewatch Elf.

The cringey, cliche-ridden dialogue, robotic acting, and a manipulative plot twist did not put me in the Christmas spirit.  It was nice to see these actors get a paycheck, but so sad to see how far Jason Biggs and Heather Graham have fallen to be in this mean-spirited garbage.
